question: Adam teaches 50 students a year. How many students will Adam teach in 10 years if in the first year he only teaches 40 students?
solution:
Adam will teach 50 * 9 = <<50*9=450>>450 students in 9 years.
So, in 10 year Adam will teach 450 + 40 = <<450+40=490>>490 students.
#### 490
clean_solution:
Adam will teach 50 * 9 = 450 students in 9 years.
So, in 10 year Adam will teach 450 + 40 = 490 students.
perturbed_solution:
Adam will teach 50 * 9 = 450 students in 9 years.
So, in 10 year Adam will teach 450 + 40 = 406 students.
completed_solution_clean:
Adam teaches 40 students in the first year. For the remaining 9 years, he teaches 50 students per year: \(50 \times 9 = 450\). Total over 10 years: \(450 + 40 = 490\).

#### 490
completed_solution_perturbed:
Adam will teach 50 students per year for the remaining 9 years after the first year:  
50 × 9 = 450 students.

Including the first year where he teaches 40 students:  
450 + 40 = 490 students.

#### 490
